meanings.definition: (Latin) to yield, submit, give way; to sink under, succumb
meanings.english_definition: (Latin) to yield, submit, give way; to sink under, succumb

usage_notes.explanation: This is the Latin infinitive form of the verb 'succumbo'. It means 'to yield, submit, give way' or 'to sink under, succumb'. It's the origin of the English word 'succumb'.

derivatives: succumbo (1st person singular present active indicative)
succubui (1st person singular perfect active indicative)

level_frequency.frequency_google_ngram: Low frequency in modern English texts, but common in Latin texts.

readability_explanation.text: This is a Latin word, so readability is dependent on Latin proficiency.

example_sentences.translation: I prefer to die than to succumb.
